Improved Education: If all humans could remember everything they read, education would become more effective as students would be able to retain information better. Teachers could provide more in-depth lessons, and students would have a deeper understanding of the subject matter.
Enhanced Creativity: With access to every piece of information ever written, people would be able to draw inspiration from any source. This could lead to new forms of art, literature, and innovation.
Increased Efficiency: People would be able to quickly recall important details, which could lead to increased productivity in various fields such as business, science, and medicine.
Loss of Privacy: The ability to remember everything would make it easier for people to track each other's activities and thoughts, potentially leading to a loss of privacy.
Memory Overload: With access to so much information, people may struggle to filter out irrelevant or outdated information. This could lead to memory overload and difficulty making decisions.
